Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: ACCURACY OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifier for the accuracyobservation for this study or step.
Column Comment.3: ACCURACY DESCRIPTION: Narrative remarks about the accuracy ortrustworthiness of a study, a step in a study or a specific result of a study. To indicatewhich specific result you are referring to, use the SYSTEM, TABLE, COLUMN andREFERENCED PPDM GUID.
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS ACCURACY TYPE: The kind of accuracy that is indicated, such as theaccuracy of transcription from paper or spreadsheet into the database, or theaccuracy of the readings that a piece of equipment can make, or the impact of acontaminant intothe sample that may render results inaccurate.
Column Comment.5: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.6: CALCULATED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value is calculated (asopposed to measured).
Column Comment.7: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value.
Column Comment.8: REFERENCE ANALYSIS CONFIDENCE TYPE: The level of confidence or certaintyfor an analysis value. Various systems for measurement are defined in literature, andmay be text based (CERTAIN, PROBABLE, UNCERTAIN) or number based. Thisvalue tends to be subjective, and indicates the level of trust the analyst has in theresult.
Column Comment.9: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.10: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.11: MEASURED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value was measured, ratherthan calculated or reported.
Column Comment.12: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.13: RAW VALUE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value is a raw value (asopposed to a calculated value).
Column Comment.14: PPDM COLUMN NAME: The name of a column that has an association with thislevel of classification system. This may be used in conjunction with an appropriateforeign key from the column that is referenced, or may be used generically incombination with the PPDM_REFERENCED_GUID, which points to the row in thecolumn that is related to the classification system level. In this case, it is essentialthat the PPDM GUID in the source table be managed carefully and appropriately.
Column Comment.15: PPDM REFERENCED GUID: The GUID in the table that has an association with thislevel of a classification system. In this case, we recommend that the name of thetable also be captured in PPDM TABLE, to make querying this information easier.Usually, the PP
Column Comment.16: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema.
Column Comment.17: PPDM TABLE NAME: The name of a table that has an association with this level of aclassification system. This may be used in conjunction with an appropriate foreignkey from the table that is referenced, or may be used generically in combination withthe
Column Comment.18: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.19: REFERENCE ANALYSIS REPEATABILITY TYPE: The level of repeatability for astudy result. Indicates how consistently the same or a similar result will be obtainedwhen a step is repeated. A result may be highly repeatable, but still incorrect ornottrustworthy. For example a sample contaminant may affect your trust in the data,even though you get the same (incorrect) answer again and again. Equipmentcapabilities may also result in a highly repeatable but inaccurate result.
Column Comment.20: REPORTED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value is provided as reportedby the source, usually a laboratory. This indicates that the value was not created ormodified upon load into PPDM, even though the value may not be correct. Ifproblems are suspected, set PROBLEM_IND to Y, and for more details about whatproblems may exist, refer to the ANL_PROBLEM table.
Column Comment.21: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.22: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample.
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
